name: Bois de Boulogne (Lakes & Allées)
full_description: Vast western park with lakes, wooded allées and long gravel paths. Leashed dogs are welcome through much of the park; plan loops around Lac Supérieur and Lac Inférieur for water views. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Bois de Vincennes (Lac Daumesnil)
full_description: Eastern counterpart to Boulogne with broad meadows, four lakes and island bridges. Leashed dogs are common on perimeter paths—check signs for no‑dog zones and nesting areas. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Parc des Buttes‑Chaumont
full_description: Romantic, hilly park with a lake, grotto and temple viewpoint; winding paths offer natural shade. Dogs are welcome on leash; choose quieter hours to avoid crowds on narrow paths. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Parc Montsouris
full_description: Large English‑style park in the south with rolling lawns, a lake and plenty of benches for water breaks. Leashed dogs are fine on main paths—respect posted lawn rules. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Coulée Verte René‑Dumont (Promenade Plantée)
full_description: An elevated linear park on a former railway viaduct with treetop views and pocket gardens. Leashed dogs can enjoy varied textures and city outlooks; avoid peak times. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Berges de Seine (Rive Droite & Gauche)
full_description: Pedestrianized riverbanks with long, flat promenades perfect for steady leash walks and people‑watching. Bring a mat for café stops on the quais. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Canal Saint‑Martin Promenade
full_description: Leafy canal‑side towpaths with iron footbridges and waterside cafés; great for unhurried loops. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Parc Monceau
full_description: Elegant oval park ringed by mansions; flat gravel paths suit quick morning laps with your dog. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Parc Rives de Seine – Île aux Cygnes Access
full_description: A narrow, leafy island path between the Eiffel Tower and the Statue of Liberty replica; flat and breezy. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Parc de Belleville
full_description: Terraced garden on a hillside with big east‑Paris views; pocket lawns and pergolas offer shade for breaks. Expect broad paths and mixed terrain that’s kind to paws, with shade pockets and benches for water breaks. Go early or at golden hour in summer to avoid heat; bring a collapsible bowl and extra bags. Leash rules vary by area—check signage at each entrance and respect protected habitats.

name: Coutume Café
full_description: Specialty‑coffee pioneer with calm, sunlit seating; outside tables suit polite, leashed dogs. Staff are used to well‑behaved dogs; outdoor tables are shaded and water bowls are usually available. Aim for off‑peak hours if your dog is still practicing calm café manners and bring a mat or chew to help them settle. Always keep your companion leashed and tucked under the table for everyone’s comfort.

name: Du Pain et des Idées
full_description: Beloved bakery famous for the ‘pain des amis’ and escargots; grab‑and‑go pastries and enjoy them canalside with your dog. Staff are used to well‑behaved dogs; outdoor tables are shaded and water bowls are usually available. Aim for off‑peak hours if your dog is still practicing calm café manners and bring a mat or chew to help them settle. Always keep your companion leashed and tucked under the table for everyone’s comfort.

name: La Fontaine de Belleville
full_description: Classic café with terrace culture done right—bistro chairs, shade and staff used to four‑legged neighbors. Staff are used to well‑behaved dogs; outdoor tables are shaded and water bowls are usually available. Aim for off‑peak hours if your dog is still practicing calm café manners and bring a mat or chew to help them settle. Always keep your companion leashed and tucked under the table for everyone’s comfort.

name: Marché des Enfants Rouges
full_description: Historic covered market with global food counters; best with dogs at quieter hours, then picnic in nearby Square du Temple. Staff are used to well‑behaved dogs; outdoor tables are shaded and water bowls are usually available. Aim for off‑peak hours if your dog is still practicing calm café manners and bring a mat or chew to help them settle. Always keep your companion leashed and tucked under the table for everyone’s comfort.

name: Le Bristol Paris
full_description: Palace‑level service with pet‑friendly rooms; concierge can suggest discreet walking routes to Parc Monceau. Check size limits and fees before booking, and ask about bowls, beds or welcome treats. Nearby green pockets make early‑morning potty breaks easy; keep wipes and extra bags in your daypack. Quiet, interior rooms are usually best for sound‑sensitive dogs.

name: Hôtel des Grands Boulevards
full_description: Romantic‑meets‑retro hotel with leafy courtyard; clear pet policy and easy access to covered passages on rainy days. Check size limits and fees before booking, and ask about bowls, beds or welcome treats. Nearby green pockets make early‑morning potty breaks easy; keep wipes and extra bags in your daypack. Quiet, interior rooms are usually best for sound‑sensitive dogs.

name: Mama Shelter Paris East
full_description: Playful, budget‑friendly stay that welcomes pets; head to nearby Père‑Lachaise perimeter for quiet laps. Check size limits and fees before booking, and ask about bowls, beds or welcome treats. Nearby green pockets make early‑morning potty breaks easy; keep wipes and extra bags in your daypack. Quiet, interior rooms are usually best for sound‑sensitive dogs.

name: CHV Frégis (Arcueil)
full_description: Renowned hospital just south of Paris with 24/7 emergency, advanced imaging and board‑certified specialists. Save the phone number in your contacts and note the closest 24/7 alternative for backup. Ask about quiet waiting options if your dog is anxious, and bring medical history or EU Pet Passport if available. For emergencies, call ahead so the team can prepare triage.

name: Advetia – Hôpital Vétérinaire Paris Ouest
full_description: Modern 24/7 hospital on the west side offering ER, ICU and a full range of specialties; easy access from the Périphérique. Save the phone number in your contacts and note the closest 24/7 alternative for backup. Ask about quiet waiting options if your dog is anxious, and bring medical history or EU Pet Passport if available. For emergencies, call ahead so the team can prepare triage.

name: CHV Pommery (Reims – regional)
full_description: Not in Paris but a key regional referral with 24/7 emergency and advanced surgery—useful for travelers crossing east. Save the phone number in your contacts and note the closest 24/7 alternative for backup. Ask about quiet waiting options if your dog is anxious, and bring medical history or EU Pet Passport if available. For emergencies, call ahead so the team can prepare triage.

name: VétoAdom (SOS Vétérinaires à Domicile)
full_description: Emergency vets who come to your home/hotel across Paris; triage by phone and dispatch within set zones. Save the phone number in your contacts and note the closest 24/7 alternative for backup. Ask about quiet waiting options if your dog is anxious, and bring medical history or EU Pet Passport if available. For emergencies, call ahead so the team can prepare triage.

name: Clinique Vétérinaire Saint‑Martin
full_description: Neighborhood clinic a few steps from the canal; preventive care, dentistry and minor surgery with kind handling. Save the phone number in your contacts and note the closest 24/7 alternative for backup. Ask about quiet waiting options if your dog is anxious, and bring medical history or EU Pet Passport if available. For emergencies, call ahead so the team can prepare triage.

name: Clinique Vétérinaire du 15e – Convention
full_description: Trusted practice for routine visits in the southwest; clear communication and easy transport links. Save the phone number in your contacts and note the closest 24/7 alternative for backup. Ask about quiet waiting options if your dog is anxious, and bring medical history or EU Pet Passport if available. For emergencies, call ahead so the team can prepare triage.

name: Tom&Co Paris – Nation
full_description: Chain pet store with solid food, harness and travel gear selection; staff can help with fit checks.

name: Waf Waf Dog Grooming (11e)
full_description: Low‑stress grooming focusing on patient handling and coat health; book ahead for weekends.

name: Paris Dogs – Éducation & Balades
full_description: Reward‑based training, social walks and daycare services designed for busy Parisian routines.

name: Café de Flore
full_description: Iconic Saint‑Germain café with wrap‑around terrace perfect for people‑watching after a riverside walk. Staff are used to well‑behaved dogs on leash; outdoor tables are close together so bring a short lead.

name: Bois de Boulogne – Allée des Chiens
full_description: The Bois de Boulogne is Paris’s western green lung, and the Allée des Chiens is its most famous off‑leash area. Dogs can run free along shaded forest paths and even swim in small lakes nearby.

name: Les Deux Magots
full_description: Historic literary café, dogs seen often on terrace. Great for post‑Luxembourg stroll with pup.

name: Angelina (Rivoli)
full_description: Belle‑Époque tea room, terrace dog‑friendly, popular for hot chocolate.

name: Bois de Vincennes – Lac Daumesnil Dog Zone
full_description: Eastern Paris forest with canine areas near lakes. Leash in most parts, off‑leash zones marked.

name: Parc Montsouris (dog areas)
full_description: Landscaped park with dog‑allowed alleys, fountains nearby.

name: Coulée Verte René‑Dumont
full_description: Elevated greenway on old railway viaduct; leash required; calm in mornings.

name: Canal Saint‑Martin Riverside
full_description: Flat canal‑side walk with iron footbridges and cafés; lively in afternoons.

name: Forêt de Fontainebleau
full_description: Huge forest ~1h from Paris, sandy trails, boulders, pine groves. Dogs love it.

name: Île de Loisirs de Cergy‑Pontoise
full_description: Expansive leisure area with lakeside loops and picnic lawns. Dogs on leash around lakes.

name: Île de Loisirs de Vaires‑Torcy
full_description: 350‑hectare recreation base with rowing basin. Dogs leashed near banks, not on beaches.

name: Étangs de Meudon
full_description: Woodland ponds with shaded banks and soft ground. Leash required.
